case_data.name: Electronic Frontier Foundation v. Department of Justice
case_data.plaintiff_description: A nonprofit organization that focuses on civil liberty issues related to technology
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
special_collections: Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act -- All Matters
case_data.summary:
On October 26, 2011, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a nonprofit civil liberties organization, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). EFF, represented by its own lawyers, asked the court for injunctive relief, claiming that the DOJ was withholding agency records concerning the DOJ's interpretation and use of Section 215 of the Patriot Act without legitimate justification under any of the limited exemptions in the FOIA. Specifically, EFF claimed that the DOJ failed to expedite the processing of the requests (despite granting the request for expediting the process), denied the plaintiff's request for a public interest fee waiver, and failed to respond within the twenty-day deadline for the processing of a non-expedited FOIA request. On November 3, 2011, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint further detailing the government's withholding of records.

On February 16, 2012, Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers granted the parties' proposed stipulation regarding the processing of the FOIA requests. The stipulation set a schedule for responding to the plaintiffs' FOIA request. (The schedule underwent several modifications during the litigation.) In addition, the Director of National Intelligence declassified and released to the public certain information related to the "business records" provision of FISA following the unauthorized disclosure of a top secret U.S. court document. As a result, the DOJ had to determine what effect, if any, this release of documents had on the classification of information in some of the withheld documents at issue in this case.

On September 6, 2013, Judge Gonzalez Rogers denied the parties' respective motions for summary judgment, without prejudice. Judge Gonzalez Rogers also ordered the DOJ to release to the plaintiff non-exempt records responsive to the plaintiff's request for significant opinions or orders of the FISC and any significant documents, procedures, or legal analyses incorporated into FISC opinions or orders that the DOJ or NSA has treated as binding. Judge Gonzalez Rogers also ordered the DOJ to complete further re-review of the remaining responsive records.

As a result of this September 2013 order, the government released hundreds of pages of previously secret FISA documents detailing the court's interpretation of Section 215, including an opinion excoriating the NSA for misusing its mass surveillance database for years. In October 2013, the government released a second batch of documents related to Section 215, which showed, among other things, that the NSA had collected cell site location without notifying its oversight committees in Congress or the FISA court. The EFF continued to argue for further disclosures of documents that the government was withholding. The government claimed that these documents were exempt from release.

On June 13, 2014, Judge Gonzalez Rogers ordered the DOJ to produce the following documents for in camera inspection by the Court to assist the Court in making a responsible de novo determination whether the documents were clearly exempt from disclosure under the FOIA: (1) FISC opinion dated 8/20/2008 (6 pages); (2) FISC order dated 10/31/2006 (19 pages); (3) FISC orders dated 2/17/2006 (17 pages); (4) FISC orders dated 2/24/2006 (8 pages); and (5) FISC orders dated 12/16/2005 (16 pages).

On July 24, 2014, Judge Gonzalez Rogers issued a second order for the DOJ to produce unredacted copies of (1) the Census Memorandum; and (2) the complete application of the DOJ in connection with which the Census Memorandum was submitted to the FISC to assist the Court in making a responsible de novo determination whether the withheld documents are clearly exempt from disclosure under FOIA. The DOJ had earlier argued that it was properly withholding a 2010 OLC memorandum which provided advice to the Department of Commerce regarding the interaction between disclosure provisions in the Patriot Act, and prohibitions on disclosure in the Census Act (‘Census Memorandum’).

On August 11, 2014, the court granted in part and denied in part the cross-motions. It held that the DOJ had established a proper basis for withholding, in full, the FISC orders and opinions at issue, and for withholding all names of telecommunications providers participating in the Call Records Collection Program, under FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3. However, the court also found that DOJ had not established that the Census Memorandum was properly withheld under Exemption 5. 2014 WL 3945646, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 110785.

On August 15, 2015, the parties reached a settlement of plaintiff’s claim for attorney’s fees, costs and expenses pursuant to the FOIA without need for further litigation. The amount was not stipulated in the notice of settlement.

The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In 2011, a nonprofit civil liberties organization filed a federal lawsuit in the Northern District of California under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The plaintiff asked the court to order the processing of a FOIA request submitted to the DOJ for documents concerning the DOJ's interpretation and use of Section 215 of the Patriot Act. The DOJ had failed to respond to the FOIA request within the allotted amount of time. In August 2014, the court held that the DOJ had established a proper basis for withholding, in full, the FISC orders and opinions at issue, and for withholding all names of telecommunications providers participating in the Call Records Collection Program, under FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3. However, the court also found that DOJ had not established that the Census Memorandum was properly withheld under Exemption 5. The parties reached a settlement for attorney’s fees without need for further litigation in August 2015. The case is now closed.

1.  This is an action under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, for 
18 
injunctive and other appropriate relief.  Plaintiff seeks the expedited processing and release of 
19 
records that Plaintiff requested from Defendant Department of Justice and its components, Office 
20 
of Legal Counsel, Office of Information Policy, National Security Division, and Federal Bureau of 
21 
Investigation, concerning the agency’s interpretation and use of Section 215 of the USA PATRIOT 
22 
Act.  The requested records concern a matter about which there is an “urgency to inform the public 
23 
about an actual or alleged [f]ederal [g]overnment activity,” and the requests were “made by a 
24 
person primarily engaged in disseminating information.”  5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(I), (v)(II); 
25 
28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(1)(ii). Expedition is also warranted because the request involves a “matter of 
26 
widespread  and  exceptional  media  interest  in  which  there  exist  possible  questions  about  the 
27 
government’s integrity which affect public confidence.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(II); 28 C.F.R. 
28

§ 16.5(d)(1)(iv). Therefore, Plaintiff is statutorily entitled to the expedited treatment it seeks.

PARTIES 
3 
2.  Plaintiff  Electronic  Frontier  Foundation  (EFF)  is  a  not-for-profit  corporation 
4 
established under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, with offices in San Francisco, 
5 
California and Washington, D.C.  EFF is a donor-supported membership organization that works to 
6 
inform policymakers and the general public about civil liberties issues related to technology and to 
7 
act as a defender of those liberties.  In support of its mission, EFF uses the FOIA to obtain and 
8 
disseminate information concerning the activities of federal agencies.    
9 
3.  Defendant Department of Justice (DOJ) is a Department of the Executive Branch of 
10 
the United States Government. DOJ is an “agency” within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. § 552(f). The 
11 
Office of Legal Counsel (OLC), Office of Information Policy (OIP),1 National Security Division 
12 
(NSD), and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) are components of Defendant DOJ. 
13

1  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS  
2  Section 215 of the USA PATRIOT Act 
3  7.  Since its passage in 2001, the USA PATRIOT Act (the “Patriot Act”), Pub. L. 
4  No. 107-56, 115 Stat. 272 (codified in various sections), has engendered controversy. In particular, 
5  the government’s use of one provision — Section 215 — has consistently sparked concern among 
6  elected officials, civil liberties advocates, and citizens.  
7  8.  Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which amended the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance 
8  Act (“FISA”), Pub. L. No. 95-511, 92 Stat. 1783 (codified in §§ 50 U.S.C. 1801 - 1885) provides 
9  the FBI with the power to obtain a court order for “any tangible thing” upon certification that the 
10  requested  items  are  “relevant  to  an  authorized  [counterintelligence  or  counterterrorism] 
11  investigation.” 50 U.S.C. § 1861(a)(1), (b)(2)(A). Section 215 — along with Section 206 (the 
12  “roving wiretap” provision) of the Patriot Act and the “lone wolf” provision of the Intelligence 
13  Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 — was initially schedule to sunset in 2005, but, 
14  after brief extensions, was subsequently reauthorized for four additional years. 
15  9.  In 2009, DOJ attorneys publicly disclosed that Section 215 orders were being used 
  16  to support a “sensitive collection program.” Statement of Todd Hinnen, Deputy Assistant Attorney 
17  General, House Judiciary Committee, “The USA PATRIOT Act,” (September 22, 2009).2  Shortly 
18  after this disclosure, elected officials briefed on the government’s interpretation of Section 215 
19  began to question the legitimacy of the government’s use of its expanded Patriot Act powers. 
20  Senator  Richard  Durbin,  a  member  of  the  Senate  Judiciary  Committee,  stated  that  the 
21  government’s use of “Section 215 is unfortunately cloaked in secrecy. Some day that cloak will be 
22  lifted, and future generations will ask whether our actions today meet the test of a democratic 
23  society: transparency, accountability, and fidelity to the rule of law and our Constitution.” Remarks 
24  of Sen. Richard Durbin, Senate Judiciary Committee “Executive Business Meeting,” (October 1, 
25  2009). 3 
26 
                                                 
27  2 Available at http://www.justice.gov/ola/testimony/111-1/2009-09-22-nsd-hinnen-patriot-act.pdf 
3 Available at http://judiciary.senate.gov/resources/webcasts/index.cfm?changedate=09-28-
28  09&p=all (beginning at 68:00).  
 
  -3-   
  FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT           CASE NO. 11-CV-5221 DMR   
 
 
 
 

 
  Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document9   Filed11/03/11   Page4 of 11
 
1 
10.  Similarly,  then-Senator  Russ  Feingold,  a  member  of  both  the  Senate  Judiciary 
2 
Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, stated: there “is information about the 
3 
use of Section 215 orders that I believe Congress and the American people deserve to know . . . 
4 
before we decide whether and in what form to extend these authorities, Congress and the American 
5 
people deserve to know at least basic information about how they have been used.” Statement of 
6 
Sen. Russ Feingold, Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing, “Reauthorizing the USA PATRIOT Act: 
7 
Ensuring  Liberty  and  Security,”  September  23,  2009.4  Despite  the  Senators’  admonitions, 
8 
Section 215 was reauthorized until 2011. 
9 
11.  In May 2011, during truncated debate on the reauthorization of the three expiring 
10 
provisions, two Senators on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence again voiced concerns 
11 
about the government’s use of 215 orders. In an interview, Senator Ron Wyden stated that he was 
12 
“extremely interested in reforming [Section 215]” and that “the public has a right to public debate 
13 
about” the government’s interpretation and use of Section 215. Spencer Ackerman, There’s a 
14 
Secret Patriot Act, Senator Says, WIRED (May 27, 2011).5 Then, in a speech on the Senate floor, 
15 
Senator Wyden declared:  
  16 
I want to deliver a warning this afternoon: when the American people find out 
17  how  their  government  has  secretly  interpreted  the  Patriot  Act,  they  will  be 
stunned and they will be angry. . . . The fact is that anyone can read the plain text 
18  of the Patriot Act, and yet many members of Congress have no idea how the law 
is being secretly interpreted by the executive branch[.]  
19 
Statement of Sen. Ron Wyden, On Patriot Act Reauthorization (May 26, 2011).6 Senator Mark 
20 
Udall echoed similar concerns about the scope of Section 215: “Congress is granting powers to the 
21 
Executive  Branch  that  lead  to  abuse,  and  frankly  shield  the  Executive  Branch  from 
22 
accountability . . . I cannot believe that we are once again being rushed into rubber-stamp policies 
23 
that threaten the liberty of the American people.”  Statement of Sen. Mark Udall, On Patriot Act 
24

Reauthorization (May 26, 2011).7

12.  Senators Wyden and Udall co-sponsored an amendment to the reauthorization of the 
3 
Patriot Act. The amendment would have required government officials to “not secretly reinterpret 
4 
public laws and statutes in a manner that is inconsistent with the public’s understanding of these 
5 
laws, and [to] not describe the execution of these laws in a way that misinforms or misleads the 
6 
public.” S.A. 339 to S. 1038, 112th Cong. § 3 (2011). The amendment would have also required 
7 
the Attorney General to publish “the legal basis for the intelligence collection activities described 
8 
in [a] February 2, 2011 report [from the Attorney General and Director of National Intelligence 
9 
regarding intelligence collection authorities scheduled to expire under Section 224 of the Patriot 
10 
Act].”  Id.  Again, over the objection of Senators briefed on the government’s interpretation and 
11 
use of Section 215, the three expiring provisions of the Patriot Act were extended until 2014. 
12 
13.  On September 21, 2011, Senators Wyden and Udall sent a joint letter to Attorney 
13 
General Eric Holder describing the DOJ’s pattern of “misleading statements pertaining to the 
14 
government’s interpretation” of Section 215. Letter from Sens. Wyden and Udall to Attorney 
15 
General  Eric  Holder  (Sept.  21,  2011).8  The  Senators  expressed  particular  concern  with 
  16 
representations made by the DOJ analogizing the use of Section 215 to grand jury subpoenas, as 
17 
well as with DOJ statements denying that Section 215 had not been subject to a secret legal 
18 
interpretation by the DOJ. Id. The Senators closed by urging DOJ to “avoid a negative public 
19 
reaction and erosion of confidence in US intelligence agencies” by “initiat[ing] an informed public 
20 
debate about these authorities today.”  Id.     
21

Plaintiff requested under the FOIA all agency records (including, but not limited to, electronic

25 
or any of its component’s interpretation or use of Section 215, including:

for  Section  215  orders  from  the  Foreign  Intelligence  Surveillance

any other record related to the number of U.S. persons identified as

subjects in Section 215 orders and the number of non-U.S. persons 
identified as subjects in Section 215 orders;

23  (8)  Copies of any invoices, receipts, bills, or any other similar document 
sent  to  the  FBI  by  any  business  or  organization  in  order  to  be 
24  reimbursed for the cost of compliance with a Section 215 order.   
25  15.  In its June 2 letters, Plaintiff also formally requested that the processing of these 
26  requests be expedited because they pertain to information about which there is “[a]n urgency to 
27  inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity,” and the requests were 
28  “made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(I),

§ 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(II); 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(1)(iv). Plaintiff further requested a waiver of all fees

request  was  in  the  public  interest,  pursuant  to  5  U.S.C.  §  552(a)(4)(A)(iii)  and  28  C.F.R.

§ 16.11(k)(1).

request, described in paragraphs 14 & 15, on June 3, 2011.

Defendant’s Failure to Provide Expedited Processing and Release of Requested Records 
2 
36.  Despite  OLC,  OIP,  and  FBI’s  grant  of  expedited  processing,  after  nearly  five 
3 
months, these three components have yet to process and release any records responsive to EFF’s 
4 
FOIA request. Not only have these components failed to expedite the processing of Plaintiff’s 
5 
requests, they have also exceeded the generally applicable twenty-day deadline for the processing 
6 
of any FOIA request.

8 
possession, it has withheld an unknown number of responsive records in full. NSD has failed to 
9 
timely respond to Plaintiff’s administrative appeal within the twenty-day determination deadline.

11 
its FOIA requests referenced herein.

CAUSES OF ACTION 
14 
Violation of the Freedom of Information Act for Failure to Expedite Processing

17 
FOIA requests.

19 
Defendant’s failure to expedite the processing of Plaintiff’s requests.

21 
the requested agency records.

Violation of the Freedom of Information Act for Wrongful Withholding of Agency Records 
23 
44.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges paragraphs 1-39.   
24 
45.  Defendant has wrongfully withheld agency records requested by Plaintiff by failing 
25 
to comply with the statutory time limit for the processing of FOIA requests. 
26 
46.  Plaintiff  has  exhausted  the  applicable  administrative  remedies  with  respect  to 
27 
Defendant’s wrongful withholding of the requested records. 
28

47.  Plaintiff is entitled to injunctive relief with respect to the release and disclosure of 
2 
the requested documents. 
3 
Violation of the Freedom of Information Act for Failure to Grant Plaintiff’s Fee Waiver 
4 
48.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges paragraphs 1-39. 
5 
49.  Defendant has wrongfully failed to grant Plaintiff’s request for a public interest fee 
6 
waiver. 
7 
50.  Plaintiff  has  exhausted  the  applicable  administrative  remedies  with  respect  to 
8 
Defendant’s failure to grant Plaintiff’s public interest fee waiver. 
9 
51.   Plaintiff is entitled to a waiver of all fees associated with the processing and release 
10 
of the requested records.  
11 
REQUESTED RELIEF 
12 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff prays that this Court: 
13 
1.      order Defendant and its components to process immediately the requested records in 
14 
their entirety; 
15 
2.  order Defendant and its components, upon completion of such expedited processing, 
  16 
to disclose the requested records in their entirety and make copies available to 
17 
Plaintiff; 
18 
3.  order Defendant and its components to waive all fees associated with the processing 
19 
and release of the requested records; 
20 
4.  provide for expeditious proceedings in this action; 
21 
5.  award Plaintiff its costs and reasonable attorneys fees incurred in this action; and 
22 
6.  grant such other relief as the Court may deem just and proper. 
23

    STIPULATION AND [PROPOSED] ORDER REGARDING FOIA   
REQUEST 
CASE NO. 4:11-CV-05221-YGR 
 
 
 
 

 
  Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document22   Filed02/16/12   Page2 of 5
 
1 
  Plaintiff  Electronic  Frontier  Foundation  and  Defendant  Department  of  Justice  and  its 
2 
components Office of Information Policy, Office of Legal Counsel, National Security Division, 
3 
and Federal Bureau of Investigation hereby stipulate to the following regarding Plaintiff’s requests 
4 
made pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (“FOIA”), dated June 2, 2011 (the “FOIA 
5 
Requests”), and the subject of the above-captioned action: 
6 
  1.  The processing and production of records responsive to Plaintiff’s FOIA Requests 
7 
will occur in three phases. On or before the date of completion for each phase, Defendant will 
8 
process and produce records according to the schedule set forth below, or notify Plaintiff of the 
9 
complete or partial withholding of responsive records, if any, pursuant to any applicable FOIA 
10 
exemptions.   
11 
  2.  The first two stages concern only the following categories of documents:  
12 
     a.  Legal opinions or memoranda concerning or interpreting Section 215 of the 
13 
USA PATRIOT Act (“Section 215”); 
14 
     b.  Guidelines for government personnel regarding the use of Section 215; 
15 
     c.  Reports provided to Congress by the Federal Bureau of Investigation or 
  16 
Department of Justice concerning or memorializing the Executive Branch’s interpretation or use of 
17 
Section 215. 
18 
     d.  Reports, opinions, or memoranda of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance 
19 
Court (“FISC”) concerning or interpreting Section 215; and 
20 
     e.  Legal opinions or memoranda concerning or interpreting rulings, opinions, 
21 
or memoranda of the FISC interpreting Section 215. 
22 
  3.  On or before March 15, 2012, Defendant will process and produce to Plaintiff those 
23 
responsive records listed in Paragraph 2 and created from March 9, 2006 to the date Defendant 
24 
began its search for responsive records.  
25 
  4.  On or before May 15, 2012, Defendant will endeavor to process and produce to 
26 
Plaintiff those responsive records listed in Paragraph 2 and created from January 1, 2004 to March 
27 
8, 2006. 
28 
  -1-   
    STIPULATION AND [PROPOSED] ORDER REGARDING FOIA   
REQUEST 
CASE NO. 4:11-CV-05221-YGR 
 
 
 
 

 
  Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document22   Filed02/16/12   Page3 of 5
 
1 
  5.  On or before July 1, 2012, Defendant will endeavor to process and produce to 
2 
Plaintiff the following categories of records: 
3 
     a.  All email responsive to Plaintiff’s FOIA Requests 
4 
     b.  All copies of invoices, receipts, bills, or any other similar document sent to 
5 
the Department of Justice or any of its components by any business or organization in order to be 
6 
reimbursed for the cost of compliance with a Section 215 order from January 1, 2004 to June 2, 
7 
2011   
8 
  6.  The following categories of documents are excluded from the FOIA Requests: 
9 
     a.  Drafts of documents listed in Paragraph 2 for which a final version is either 
10 
identified and withheld, or partially released, pursuant to a valid FOIA exemption, or released in 
11 
full; 
12 
     b.  Emails concerning the drafts of documents described in Paragraph 6(a) for 
13 
which a final version is either identified and withheld, or partially released, pursuant to a valid 
14 
FOIA exemption, or released in full; 
15 
     c.  Records  that  are  purely  logistical,  such  as  emails  between  officials 
  16 
attempting to schedule a meeting.  
17 
  7.  For  email  responsive  to  Plaintiff’s  FOIA  Requests,  only  one  version  of  every 
18 
responsive email need be processed and released or withheld in full pursuant to a valid FOIA 
19 
exemption.   
20 
  8.  Acquisition applications and supporting documentation submitted to the Foreign 
21 
Intelligence Surveillance Court are excluded from the FOIA Request. 
22 
  9.  With respect to the Office of Legal Counsel (“OLC”), OLC need only process and 
23 
release, or withhold pursuant to a valid FOIA exemption, OLC legal opinions and memoranda 
24 
concerning or interpreting Section 215.  
25 
  10.  Within 21 days of the completion of the productions and/or notifications set forth in 
26 
Paragraphs 1 – 5, above, the parties will meet and confer regarding the documents withheld in 
27 
whole or in part by Defendant, and Plaintiff will notify Defendant whether it wishes to object to 
28 
  -2-   
    STIPULATION AND [PROPOSED] ORDER REGARDING FOIA   
REQUEST 
CASE NO. 4:11-CV-05221-YGR 
 
 
 
 

 
  Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document22   Filed02/16/12   Page4 of 5
 
1 
any of the withholdings. In the event Plaintiff objects, the parties will discuss a scheduling order 
2 
for whether, how, or when Defendant will provide an index or other description of partially or 
3 
completely withheld documents pursuant to Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973).  
4 
  11.  Within 30 days of the completion of productions and/or notifications set forth in 
5 
Paragraphs 1 – 5, above, the parties will submit a joint statement to the Court describing the status 
6 
of the case.      
7 
  12.  Defendant enters into this stipulation based on the information available to it at this 
8 
time.  In the event unforeseen circumstances arise, such as an unexpectedly high volume of 
9 
responsive material or problems processing Plaintiff’s FOIA Requests, Defendant reserves the right 
10 
to seek an extension of time after meeting and conferring with Plaintiff through counsel. 
11   
DATED:  February 10, 2012  Respectfully submitted, 
12 
  By   /s/ Mark Rumold

documents.title: Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment
documents.text:
Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document90   Filed08/11/14   Page1 of 13
 
 
1  
 
2  
 
3  
 
4  
 
5  
 
6 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
7  
 
8  
ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION,  Case No.: 4:11-cv-05221-YGR 
9    
 
  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN 
 Pl aintiff, 
10  
PART CROSS-MOTIONS FOR SUMMARY 
   
11  vs.    JUDGMENT  (DKT. NOS. 77 AND 79) 
ourt  ornia  12  DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE,        
C if 13  
t  al  Defendant. 
c C
stri of  14
Di t 
c Presently before the Court are the renewed cross-motions for summary judgment on the claim 
s  ri 15
e t
Stat  Dis 16 of plaintiff Electronic Frontier Foundation (“EFF” or “Plaintiff”) under the Freedom of Information 
d  rn
e e Act (“FOIA”), 5 U.S.C. § 522.  EFF alleges that defendant Department of Justice (“DOJ”) is 
t h 17
ni rt
U o
N 18 withholding agency records without legitimate justification under any of the limited exemptions in 
the statute.  (Dkt. Nos. 77 and 79.)  DOJ responds that information concerning the details of a 
19
government counter-terrorism program undertaken pursuant to Section 215 of the USA PATRIOT 
20
Act, 50 U.S.C. § 1861(a)(1), (“Section 215”), including the documents sought by EFF containing 
21
significant legal interpretation of the government’s authority under Section 215, is exempt from 
22
disclosure under FOIA.  
23
By way of background, the parties previously filed and argued cross-motions for summary 
24
judgment, and supplemented briefing as to the sufficiency of the public identification of the 
25
documents withheld and the basis therefor in response to this Court’s order.  While those cross-
26
motions were still pending, certain classified information was the subject of unauthorized 
27
disclosures, widely reported in the press.  These unauthorized disclosures led to the government’s 
28
declassification and production of hundreds of pages of formerly highly classified documents that 
 

Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document90   Filed08/11/14   Page2 of 13
 
1 discuss, among other things, the collection of telephony metadata pursuant to Section 215 of the 
2 USA PATRIOT Act (“the call record collection program”).  Apparently among the declassified 
3 documents were many documents responsive to EFF’s FOIA request and previously withheld.   
4 The parties agreed that further summary judgment briefing would be necessary to resolve the 
5 propriety of the remaining withholdings.  Pursuant to the parties’ stipulation, the Court ordered that 
further summary judgment briefing would be based on a “representative sample” of withheld 
6
records.  (See Stipulation at Dkt. No. 71; Order at Dkt. No. 72.)  In its opposition and cross-motion, 
7
EFF further narrowed its challenge to DOJ’s: (1) withholding, in full, of any opinion or order of the 
8
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (“FISC”); (2) withholding of the names of 
9
telecommunication service providers participating in the call record collection program under 
10
Section 215; and (3) withholding, in full, of a formal opinion of the Office of Legal Counsel 
11
(“OLC”) described in the Declaration of Paul P. Colborn (Dkt. No. 77-5) as a memorandum provided 
12
a 
rt  ni 13 to the Department of Commerce dated January 4, 2010 regarding “the interaction between disclosure 
u r
o o
C if in the Patriot Act, as amended, and prohibitions in the Census Act.” (Id. at ¶ 13 [describing the 
t  al 14
c C
Distri t of  15 document referred to hereinafter as “the Census Memorandum”].)  
c
es  tri The Court has thoroughly reviewed the parties’ submissions and heard oral argument on the 
tat Dis 16
d S rn  17 new cross-motions for summary judgment.  The Court has also conducted an in camera review of the 
e e
t h
ni rt ex parte, classified version of the declaration of Jennifer L. Hudson, the ex parte Declaration by the 
U o 18
N
Chief of Operations, Office of Intelligence, National Security Division, Department of Justice (“the 
19
NSD Declaration”) concerning DOJ’s use of the Census Memorandum, and certain documents at 
20
issue in the cross-motions, specifically:  
21
(1) FISC opinion dated 8/20/2008 (6 pages);  
22
(2) FISC order dated 10/31/2006 (19 pages); 
23
(3) FISC orders dated 2/17/2006 (17 pages); 
24
(4) FISC orders dated 2/24/2006 (8 pages); 
25
(5) FISC orders dated 12/16/2005 (16 pages); 
26
(6) the Census Memorandum and the related application of the Department of Justice in  
27
      connection with which the Census Memorandum was submitted to the FISC. 
28
2 

Case4:11-cv-05221-YGR   Document90   Filed08/11/14   Page3 of 13
 
1 (See Dkt. No. 77-2, Vaughn Index, at 1-3, Doc. No. 14A, 86J, 89D, 89K, 89S; see also Order dated 
2 June 13, 2014, Dkt. No. 85, and Ordered dated July 24, 2014, Dkt. No. 88.)  
3 Having carefully considered the papers and arguments submitted, and for the reasons set forth 
4 below, the Court hereby Orders that the cross-motions are GRANTED IN PART AND DENIED IN PART.  
5 DOJ has established a proper basis for withholding, in full, the FISC orders and opinions at issue, 
6 and for withholding all names of telecommunications providers participating in the Call Records

8 favor of DOJ on the claim for disclosure of this information.  However, DOJ has not established that 
9 the Census Memorandum is properly withheld under Exemption 5, and EFF is GRANTED summary 
10 judgment on its claim for FOIA violation as to this document.

Di ct  On June 11, 2013, the Court issued an order, pursuant to the stipulation of the parties, holding 
ed States  ern Distri 1156 its decision on the parties’ pending cross-motions for summary judgment in abeyance.  (Dkt. No. 
Unit orth 17 60.)  The Court granted the stipulation in light of recent developments concerning release of 
N
previously classified information by the Director of National Intelligence (“DNI”) related to Section 
18

19

http://www.odni.gov/index.php/newsroom/press-releases/191-press-releases-2013/868-dni-
21

22
Joint Status Report on July 12, 2013 (Dkt. No. 61), setting forth their respective positions regarding 
23
the timing of Defendant’s declassification review of responsive documents and release of any re-
24
classified, non-exempt documents previously withheld.   
25
On July 19, 2013, the Court ordered that Defendant submit finalized classification 
26
determinations and the dates by which it would release said documents to Plaintiff, as well as a 
27
schedule for declassification of the remainder of the documents and a proposed schedule for further 
28
 

 
1 briefing on the pending cross-motions for summary judgment in light of the above, reached after 
2 meeting and conferring with Plaintiff.  
3 Defendants have submitted a Status Report (Dkt. No. 63) addressing these points and 
4 indicating that Plaintiff does not object to review and release of the documents on the schedule set 
5 forth therein.  Moreover, the parties agree that, following the declassification review and production 
6 of documents previously withheld, “the remaining areas of dispute in this litigation will be 
7 substantially narrowed if not eliminated.”  (Id. at 3:22-24.)   
Having considered the Status Report and the significant change in the posture of the case in 
8
9 light of the developments detailed above, and good cause appearing, the Court ORDERS as follows:  
10 (1) the pending Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment are DENIED WITHOUT PREJUDICE to 
re-filing/re-noticing, if necessary, after Defendant’s release of documents; 
11
(2) Defendant shall prepare for release to Plaintiff on or before September 10, 2013, non-
12
exempt records responsive to Plaintiff’s request for: (a) significant opinions or orders of the FISC,

1  
 
2

6 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
7  
 
8  
ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION,  Case No.: 4:11-cv-05221-YGR 
9    
 
  ORDER RE: PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS 
 Pl aintiff, 
10  
FOR IN CAMERA REVIEW  
   
11  vs.   
 
   
12  
DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE,  
strict Court  of California  1134  Defendant.    
Di ct  Presently before the Court are the renewed cross-motions for summary judgment on 
ed States  ern Distri 1156 Plaintiff’s claim under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 522, that Defendant is 
Unit orth 17 withholding agency records without legitimate justification under any of the limited exemptions in 
N
the statute.  (Dkt. Nos. 77 and 79.)  The Court has thoroughly reviewed the parties’ submissions and 
18
heard oral argument on the motions.  The Court has also reviewed in camera the ex parte, classified 
19
version of the declaration of Jennifer L. Hudson, submitted in support of Defendant’s summary 
20
judgment motion.  Based upon this review, the Court ORDERS that Defendant produce pertinent 
21
documents for in camera review.  
22
In FOIA cases, a court reviews the government agency’s decision to withhold records de 
23
novo, and the government bears the burden of proving records have been properly withheld.  5 
24
U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B).  “Unlike the review of other agency action that must be upheld if supported 
25
by substantial evidence and not arbitrary or capricious, the FOIA expressly places the burden ‘on the 
26
agency to sustain its action.’”  Dep’t of Justice v. Reporters Comm. for Freedom of the Press, 489 
27
U.S. 749, 755 (1989) quoting 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B).  Thus, when claiming one of FOIA’s 
28
 

 
1 exemptions, the agency bears the burden of demonstrating to a reviewing court that withheld 
2 information is “clearly exempt.”  Birch v. USPS, 803 F.2d 1206, 1209 (D.C. Cir. 1986). 
3 District courts have broad discretion to order in camera inspection of the actual documents 
4 the agency seeks to withhold.  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B).  Lion Raisins v. U.S. Dep't of Agric., 354 
5 F.3d 1072, 1079 (9th Cir. 2004); Quinon v. F.B.I., 86 F.3d 1222, 1228 (D.C. Cir. 1996).  Such in 
camera inspection is particularly necessary when the government agency has not sustained its burden 
6
based on its testimony or declarations alone.  Lion Raisins, 354 F.3d at 1079.  In camera review is 
7
also appropriate where there is evidence to suggest that the agency has not acted in good faith, either 
8
within the FOIA action itself or in the underlying activities that generated the records sought.  
9
Quinon, 86 F.3d at 1228; Rugiero v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 257 F.3d 534, 543 (6th Cir. 2001), cert. 
10
denied, 534 U.S. 1334 (2002); Allen v. Cent. Intelligence Agency, 636 F.2d 1287, 1298 (D.C. Cir. 
11
1980) overruled on other grounds in Founding Church of Scientology of Washington, D.C., Inc. v. 
12
Smith, 721 F.2d 828 (D.C. Cir. 1983).   Further, in determining whether to undertake an in camera 
rt  nia  13
ou or review, a court must take into account concerns of judicial economy and the strength of the public’s 
ct C Calif 14
stri of  15 interest in disclosure of the documents sought.  Rugiero, 257 F.3d at 543; Allen, 636 F.2d at 1298.  
Di ct

N litigation and now declassified, had been withheld in their entirety when a disclosure of reasonably 
18
segregable portions of those documents would have been required.  Further, the withholding 
19
followed an Order from this Court expressing concern that the agency had failed to explain 
20
sufficiently why the withheld documents “would be so replete with descriptions of intelligence 
21
activities, sources and methods that no portions thereof would contain” reasonably segregable and 
22
producible, non-exempt information.  (Order Re: Further Submission on Cross-Motion for Summary 
23
Judgment, Dkt. No. 49, at 2-3.)   
24
Further, the Court finds that the public’s interest in the documents withheld is significant.  
25
The scope and legality of the government’s current surveillance practices of broad swaths of its 
26
citizenry is a topic of intense public interest and concern.  “The Freedom of Information Act was 
27
aimed at ending secret law and insuring that this country have ‘an informed, intelligent electorate.”” 
28
Allen v. Cent. Intelligence Agency, 636 F.2d 1287, 1299 (D.C. Cir. 1980), citing H.R.Rep.No.1497, 
2 

 
1 89th Cong., 2d Sess. 12 (1966) U.S.Code Cong. & Admin.News 1966, p. 2419.  In light of this 
2 public interest, in camera review to assure that the agency is complying with its obligations to 
3 disclose non-exempt material is certainly merited.  Finally, as the parties have narrowed the range of 
4 documents for review, the burden on judicial resources is not significant.   
5 Based upon the foregoing, Defendant is ORDERED to deliver to the Court the following 
documents for in camera inspection to assist the Court in making a responsible de novo 
6
determination whether the documents are clearly exempt from disclosure under the FOIA:  
7
(1) FISC opinion dated 8/20/2008 (6 pages);  
8
(2) FISC order dated 10/31/2006 (19 pages); 
9
(3) FISC orders dated 2/17/2006 (17 pages); 
10
(4) FISC orders dated 2/24/2006 (8 pages); 
11
(5) FISC orders dated 12/16/2005 (16 pages). 
12
(See Dkt. No. 77-2, Vaughn Index, at 1-3, Doc. No. 14A, 86J, 89D, 89K, 89S.)
